trial_identification.studytitle: TeleWalk: A trial of telephone-based walking promotion in older adults
trial_identification.scientifictitle: TeleWalk: A trial of telephone-based walking promotion to improve physical activity and health-related quality of life in sedentary older adults

interventions.interventions: Study Intervention - A combination of telephone-based motivational interviewing and cognitive-behavioural techniques (3-month duration).

primaryOutcome.outcome: (1) physical activity (as measured by the Auckland Heart Study Physical Activity Questionnaire)
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Assessed at baseline, at 3 months (end of intervention), and at 6 and 12 months (as follow-up).

primaryOutcome.outcome: (2) health-related quality of life (as measured by the SF-36)
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Assessed at baseline, at 3 months (end of intervention), and at 6 and 12 months (as follow-up).

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Falls and injuries are assessed via calendars completed prospectively by participants.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: These calendars are collected from participants each month for the 3-month intervention.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: 1. Sedentary (i.e., participated in less than 30 minutes of physical activity on five or more days per week for six months or longer.2. Would be living in Auckland, New Zealand for at least 12 months from the time of their recruitment to the trial.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: 1. Had a medical history or major health problem that meant walking would be contrindicated (assessed by their general practitioner).

trial_design.concealment: Computer generated random numbers were used. The researcher performing the randomisation was unaware of whom each ID number was related to.
trial_design.sequence: Computer generated random numbers were used. Patients from each of three medical clinics were randomised in blocks.

fundingsource.fundingname: National Heart Foundation of New Zealand

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The TeleWalk study is an investigation of the effectiveness of a telephone-based counseling intervention on physical activity participation and health-related quality of life in older (65 years or older) sedentary adults.
